content.description: Located on Hound Rock, this route is about five feet to the right of the route Tossed Green. Start on an easy slab which leads into the crack proper. Climb up to a rotten downward pointing flake. Surmount this (crux) and continue up the crack to the top. There are rap slings around a large boulder at the top of the crack. The poor rock on this route is in contrast to the good rock on the other Hound Rock routes.

climbs.name: Tossed Green
climbs.fa: John Long, Randy Vogel, Mike Lechlinski, Craig Fry & Mari Gingery, December 1977

content.description:
Hidden but a short distance from the crowds at Trashcan Rock is this gem of a route which if it were roadside would see almost constant traffic.

Climb a short slab, or as an alternative traverse in from the left, to reach the base of the crack which starts with a short vertical section of fingers and hands. Above this is a ledge and another short section with fingers and some stemming/liebacking to reach a second ledge. The last bit climbs up and right on face holds until able to traverse back left to reach good hand jams which lead to the top and the anchors.

The variety of moves on this coupled with the setting make for a

tradtastic

​​​​ experience. Three stars out of five.
content.protection:
Gear to 1.5 inches but include one 2.5 inch piece; wires work well

2 bolt anchor/rap
content.location:
Just left of

White Powder

, a wide crack/chimney.

climbs.name: Over The Hill
climbs.fa: Alan Bartlett and Don Wilson, May 1981

content.description: This climb is very loose and a real thrash.
content.location: The next crack to the right of White Powder.

content.description:
Climb thin seams up the face to join

Crescent Wrench

for it's last moves. Fingery and delicate climbing make this trickier than appearances might suggest.
This is the thin aching crack visible as you first reach the rock. Thin crack, thin gear, thin feet - thin! Easy walk-off to the climber's left.
content.location: The left side of Hound Rock's east face.

climbs.name: Animalitos
climbs.fa: TR: John Long, Eric Ericksson; 1980.  Lead: Unknown. [Per Vogel]

content.description: Discontinuous thin cracks (crux; hard to protect) to a crack to the top.  [per Vogel]
content.protection: Lots of thin, up to 2.5" [per Vogel]
content.location: To the right of Over the Hill, there's a notch, and then the formation gets taller again on the north end.  This route is the center crack system on that taller face.  Downclimb the back side to get off ("tricky" is how Vogel describes it).

climbs.name: Animalargos
climbs.fa: TR: John Long, Randy Vogel, Lynn Hill; 1980.  Lead: Unknown.  [per Vogel]

content.description: Up the face to a small triangular spot, then up (crux) to a thin crack.  Then head left up the crack to join Animalitos.  [per Vogel]
content.location: Start is approx 15' right of Animalitos.  Descent is via a "tricky" downclimb off the backside (Vogel's wording).

content.description:
Gain the right most of two cracks imediately above the large boulder between Crescent Wrench and Tossed Green. A tricky boulder type move leads to an off-balance crack. At the tougher end of the 5.9 continuum, with interesting moves all the way to the top. Almost on par with Tossed Green for quality.

Down climb by wandering up and back down to the left (south) above Crescent Wrench.
content.protection: Standard Josh rack to #3 camalot(including the anchor)
